Stage 1:
['The', 'Coptic', 'alphabet', 'is', 'the', 'use', 'of', 'the', 'Greek', 'alphabet', 'adapted', 'for', 'Egyptian', 'phonology', ',', 'first', 'developed', 'in', 'the', 'Ptolemaic', 'period', ',', 'and', 'gradually', 'replacing', 'the', 'use', 'of', 'the', 'Demotic', 'script', 'in', 'about', 'the', '4th', 'to', '5th', 'centuries', 'CE', '.']
The Coptic alphabet is the use of the Greek alphabet adapted for Egyptian phonology, first developed in the Ptolemaic period, and gradually replacing the use of the Demotic script in about the 4th to 5th centuries CE.
-----------------------

The Coptic alphabet is the use of the Greek alphabet adapted for Egyptian phonology, first developed in the Ptolemaic period, and gradually replacing the use of the Demotic script in about the 4th to 5th centuries CE.
-----------------------

In the language's final stage of development, the Coptic alphabet replaced the older writing system.

Stage 1:
['Hieroglyphs', 'are', 'employed', 'in', 'two', 'ways', 'in', 'Egyptian', 'texts', ':', 'as', 'ideograms', 'to', 'represent', 'the', 'idea', 'depicted', 'by', 'the', 'pictures', 'and', ',', 'more', 'commonly', ',', 'as', 'phonograms', 'to', 'represent', 'their', 'phonetic', 'value', '.']
Hieroglyphs are employed in two ways in Egyptian texts: as ideograms to represent the idea depicted by the pictures and, more commonly, as phonograms to represent their phonetic value.

Stage 1:
['Since', 'vowels', 'were', 'not', 'written', 'until', 'Coptic', ',', 'reconstructions', 'of', 'the', 'Egyptian', 'vowel', 'system', 'are', 'much', 'more', 'uncertain', 'and', 'rely', 'mainly', 'on', 'evidence', 'from', 'Coptic', 'and', 'records', 'of', 'Egyptian', 'words', ',', 'especially', 'proper', 'nouns', ',', 'in', 'other', 'languages/writing', 'systems', '.']

Stage 1:
['Vowels', 'are', 'always', 'short', 'in', 'unstressed', 'syllables', '-LRB-', '', 'tpj', '', '=', '*', '/', 'tapij', '/', '`', 'first', "'", '-RRB-', 'and', 'long', 'in', 'open', 'stressed', 'syllables', '-LRB-', '', 'rm', '', '=', '*', '/', 'ramac', '/', '`', 'man', "'", '-RRB-', ',', 'they', 'but', 'can', 'be', 'either', 'short', 'or', 'long', 'in', 'closed', 'stressed', 'syllables', '-LRB-', '', 'jnn', '', '=', '*', '/', 'janan', '/', '`', 'we', "'", ',', '', 'mn', '', '=', '*', '/', 'man', '/', '`', 'to', 'stay', "'", '-RRB-', '.']
Vowels are always short in unstressed syllables -LRB-  tpj  = * / tapij / "first" -RRB- and long in open stressed syllables -LRB-  rm  = * / ramac / "man" -RRB-, they but can be either short or long in closed stressed syllables -LRB-  jnn  = * / janan / "we",  mn  = * / man / "to stay" -RRB-.
-----------------------

Stage 2:
['Vowels', 'are', 'always', 'short', 'in', 'unstressed', 'syllables', '-LRB-', '', 'tpj', '', '=', '*', '/', 'tapij', '/', '`', 'first', "'", '-RRB-', 'and', 'long', 'in', 'open', 'stressed', 'syllables', '-LRB-', '', 'rm', '', '=', '*', '/', 'ramac', '/', '`', 'man', "'", '-RRB-', ',', 'they', 'but', 'can', 'be', 'either', 'short', 'or', 'long', 'in', 'closed', 'stressed', 'syllables', '-LRB-', '', 'jnn', '', '=', '*', '/', 'janan', '/', '`', 'we', "'", ',', '', 'mn', '', '=', '*', '/', 'man', '/', '`', 'to', 'stay', "'", '-RRB-', '.']
Vowels are always short in unstressed syllables -LRB-  tpj  = * / tapij / "first" -RRB- and long in open stressed syllables -LRB-  rm  = * / ramac / "man" -RRB-, they but can be either short or long in closed stressed syllables -LRB-  jnn  = * / janan / "we",  mn  = * / man / "to stay" -RRB-.

NNP  ,   NNP    ,   CC  JJ         JJ    VBD   DT    VBN    VBG   CC   DT      JJ       CC    JJ      NNS    . 
 |   |    |     |   |   |          |      |    |      |      |    |    |       |        |     |        |     |  
Old  ,  Middle  ,  and Late     Egyptian were all  written using both the hieroglyphic and hieratic scripts  .

The Coptic alphabet  is the     use  of the Greek alphabet adapted for Egyptian     phonology  ,  first developed  in the     Ptolemaic period  ,  and gradually replacing the     use  of the     Demotic script  in about the 4th  to      5th     centuries  CE  .

Recently  ,  some     evidence  of internal     dialects has been found  in pairs  of     similar     words  in Egyptian that  ,  based  on similarities with later     dialects      of     Coptic  ,  may  be derived from northern and southern dialects  of     Egyptian  .

     ________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________|_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________   
    |      |                     |                             VP                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |

 Recently  ,  some     evidence  of internal     dialects has been found  in pairs  of     similar     words  in Egyptian that  ,  based    on   similarities with later     dialects      of         Coptic  ,  may  be derived from northern and southern dialects  of         Egyptian  .

 IN  DT    JJ         NN      IN            NNP     MD  RB    VB    VBN             IN               NN     ,       NNPS     VBP  DT            NN        IN                NN        TO   VB    DT            NN  WDT    MD     VB       VBN        IN      DT               JJ         NN      .

 As the phonetic realisation  of          Egyptian can not    be   known           with          certainty  ,  Egyptologists use  a           system      of         transliteration  to denote each         sound that could    be   represented    by      a            uniliteral hieroglyph  . 

None
Potential Answer Phrases:

 In     addition  ,  because Egyptian  is recorded over  a  full 2000 years  ,  the Archaic and Late stages being separated  by the     amount  of     time that separates Old     Latin from Modern     Italian  ,  significant phonetic changes must have occurred during that lengthy time frame  .

Since vowels were not written until     Coptic  ,  reconstructions  of the Egyptian vowel system are much     more uncertain and rely mainly  on     evidence from Coptic and records  of Egyptian     words  ,  especially      proper nouns  ,   in other     languages/writin systems  .

Bohairic and Akhmimic are more      conservative and have  a  velar      fricative  /   x   /   .

Although the same graphemes are  used for the     pulmonic stops  ,  the     existence  of the     former may  be inferred because the      stops                         /   p       t       c       k    /  are allophonically aspirated -LSB-  p  t  c  k -RSB- before stressed vowels and sonorant     consonants  .

   IN     DT  JJ     NNS       VBP    VBN   IN  DT        JJ     NNS   ,   DT         NN     IN    DT         JJ    MD  VB   VBN       IN       DT             NNS  VBP  NN    NN    NN  NN          CD    :       NN            NN          NN          NN   :  VBP       RB           JJ    -LRB-  NN    NN    NN    NN   -RRB-   IN      JJ      NNS    CC    JJ           NNS      . 
   |      |   |       |         |      |    |   |         |       |    |   |          |      |     |          |     |   |     |        |        |               |    |   |     |     |   |           |     |       |             |           |           |    |   |        |            |       |    |     |     |     |      |     |       |        |     |     |             |       |  
Although the same graphemes    are    used for the     pulmonic stops  ,  the     existence  of   the       former may  be inferred because    the            stops                                  /       p             t           c           k    /  are allophonically aspirated -LSB-  p    t    c    k   -RSB- before stressed  vowels and sonorant     consonants  .

Vowels are always short  in unstressed     syllables and long  in open stressed syllables  ,   Vowels but can  be either short  or  long  in closed      stressed syllables  .

Vowels are always short  in unstressed         syllables and    long      in   open stressed syllables  ,    Vowels but can  be either short  or  long  in closed           stressed syllables  .

 |     |       |       |               |     |     |       |                  |      |      |         |          |      |      |   |      |      |   |   |   |     |        |        |     |             |     |     |        |      |      |      |     |       |       |      |   |           |     |     |      |        |     |     |       |               |        |         |      |     |        |       |       |       |       |      |       |         |       |        |     |     |       |     |     |             |   |     |     |   |   |     |     |     |     |   |      |       |        |              |      |     |              |   |     |     |     |      |       |       |     |        |     |   |   |  
 In Sahidic   and   Bohairic         Coptic  ,    Late  Egyptian           stressed  *      /         a         /   becomes   *   /      o     /  and  *   /     e       /     becomes  /             a    /     ,       but    are unchanged  in   the    other  dialects  :              sn         *      /       san    /     `    brother            '        >      Sahaidic and Bohairic          son             ,    Akhminic  ,  Lycopolitan   and   Fayyumic        san           ;          rn               `    name   '   *   /    rin    /     >     *   /     ren      /        >           Sahaidic and Bohairic            ran         ,  Akhminic  ,  Lycopolitan and Fayyumic        ren     . 

None
Potential Answer Phrases:
Late Egyptian stressed * / a / becomes * / o / and * / e / becomes / a /, but are unchanged in the other dialects:  sn  * / san / "brother" > Sahaidic and Bohairic  son , Akhminic, Lycopolitan and Fayyumic  san ;  rn  "name" * / rin / > * / ren / > Sahaidic and Bohairic  
, Akhminic, Lycopolitan and Fayyumic  ren

    |      |      UNMV:PP          |         |                     UNMV:PP                |             |                      |                UNMV:PP           |       |              UNMV:PP               |     |      |    |     |       |                   UNMV:VP          |   | 
    |      |    _____|_______      |         |             ___________|_______            |             |                      |            _______|_______       |       |          _______|______________    |     |      |    |     |       |              ________|_______      |   |  
UNMV:ADVP  |   |          UNMV:NP  |      UNMV:NP         |                UNMV:NP        |         UNMV:ADVP                  |           |            UNMV:NP   |       |         |       |    UNMV:NP   |   |  UNMV:NP   |    |  UNMV:NP    |             |             UNMV:NP  |   | 
    |      |   |             |     |    _____|_____       |      _____________|______     |     ________|_________             |           |               |      |       |         |       |       |      |   |     |      |    |     |       |             |                |     |   |  
    RB     ,   IN            NN    ,   DT          NN     IN    DT            JJ     NN  VBZ  RBS                 RB          VBN          IN              NN     CC     VBN        IN      ``     NNP     ''  :    PRP    VBZ   ``    NN     VBZ           VBN              PRP    ''  . 
    |      |   |             |     |   |           |      |     |             |      |    |    |                  |            |           |               |      |       |         |       |       |      |   |     |      |    |     |       |             |                |     |   |  
   Thus    ,  for         example  ,  the         name    of    an         Egyptian king  is  most            accurately transliterated    as           R-ms-sw and transcribed    as      ``   Ramesses  ''  ;     it   means  ``    Ra     has        Fashioned           Him    ''  .

 JJR        NNS  VBP  RB    JJ    CC  MD  VB   RP  TO   CD         NNS      :    NN   ``  VB      JJ           ''  . 
  |          |    |   |     |     |   |   |    |   |    |           |       |    |    |   |       |            |   |  
Larger     roots are also common and can have  up  to  five     consonants  :  sdd  ``  be upside-down       ''  .
